242002.name: 12 month prevalence of major depressive disorder
242002.datasetName: Major depressive disorder 12 month & lifetime prevalence USA – Hasin (2018)

source.name: Hasin et al. (2018)
source.dataPublishedBy: Hasin DS, Sarvet AL, Meyers JL, et al. Epidemiology of Adult DSM-5 Major Depressive Disorder and Its Specifiers in the United States. JAMA Psychiatry. 2018;75(4):336–346. doi:10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2017.4602
source.dataPublisherSource: 2012-2013 National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions III (NESARC-III)
source.additionalInfo:
This is a representative epidemiological survey of non-institutionalized US adults, carried out in 2012–2013. It contains data on the prevalence of major depressive disorder in the last 12 months and lifetime so far, based on structured interviews of participants using DSM-5 version of the Alcohol Use Disorder and Associated Disabilities Interview Schedule 5. Data was adjusted for oversampling and non-response.

Major depressive episode was diagnosed when at least 2 weeks of persistent depressed mood, anhedonia, or hopelessness occurred (reported by self or observed by others), plus additional symptoms from criterion A, for a total of 5 of the 9 DSM-5 major depression criteria and the clinical significance criterion. Lifetime DSM-5 MDD was defined as at least one lifetime major depressive episode without full DSM-5 manic, mixed, or hypomanic episodes, excluding substance-induced and medical-induced disorders. Those with at least one episode in the prior 12 months were classified as having 12-month MDD.
